content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple fragments of tissue, consistent with a lymph node dissection specimen. The tissue is predominantly fatty (adipose tissue, pale pink) with several embedded, well-circumscribed, basophilic (dark purple) nodules of varying sizes. These nodules are highly suggestive of lymph nodes. I can identify at least five to six potential lymph nodes that require microscopic examination.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I would zoom into this area because the green box highlights a well-defined, basophilic nodule embedded in adipose tissue, which is the classic low-power appearance of a lymph node. The primary task is to identify metastatic disease in lymph nodes, so I must systematically examine every potential lymph node on the slide at high magnification. This is one of the several lymph nodes I need to assess. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is a clearly identifiable lymph node. In a colorectal cancer case, a crucial part of staging is to determine if the cancer has spread to regional lymph nodes (N-staging). Therefore, every lymph node must be meticulously examined. This particular node is one of the larger and more well-circumscribed ones, making it a good candidate for initial detailed assessment. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my goal is to meticulously examine every single lymph node to determine the nodal status (pN stage). The area highlighted by the green box at the bottom right of the slide is a small, dark, basophilic focus. This appearance is highly suggestive of a lymph node or a fragment of lymphoid tissue. Even very small nodes must be assessed for metastasis. This is likely the 10th or 11th lymph node I would examine during a systematic, top-to-bottom, left-to-right review of the slide. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see a portion of a lymph node characterized by a dense, uniform population of small, round lymphocytes. The lymph node is enclosed by a thin fibrous capsule and is adjacent to mature adipose tissue (fat). There are no atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or pools of mucin to suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a benign (reactive) lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see the architecture of a lymph node. There is marked follicular hyperplasia, characterized by numerous, large, and irregularly shaped germinal centers. The overall structure is composed of lymphoid tissue, with a dense population of lymphocytes. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular formations, or nests of tumor cells that would indicate metastatic carcinoma. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view confirms the presence of lymphoid tissue. The lower portion of the image shows a dense, sheet-like population of small, dark lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm. This is consistent with the cortex or paracortex of a lymph node. The lymphoid tissue is adjacent to mature adipose tissue (fat cells) and fibrous connective tissue at the top. In this specific field of view, I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or cell nests that would indicate metastatic carcinoma. My impression is that this is a lymph node that is negative for malignancy.
